'''Memphis Willie B.''' (November 4, 1911<ref name="AMG"/> – October 5, 1993)<ref name="Dead">{{cite web|author=Doc Rock |url=http://thedeadrockstarsclub.com/1992.html |title=The Dead Rock Stars Club 1992 - 1993 |publisher=Thedeadrockstarsclub.com |date= |accessdate=2014-01-27}}</ref> was an [[United States|American]] [[Memphis blues]] guitarist, harmonica player, singer and songwriter.<ref name="AMG">{{cite web |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p24569/biography|pure_url=yes}}|title=Memphis Willie B.|author=[[Cub Koda]]|publisher=[[Allmusic]] |accessdate=October 11, 2011}}</ref> 

He was known for his work with Jack Kelly's Jug Busters, the [[Memphis Jug Band]], and his resurgence in the 1960s after years away from the [[music industry]].<ref name="AMG"/> He recorded "The Stuff Is Here" and "Stop Cryin' Blues".<ref name="Dead"/> His 1961 song, "Overseas Blues", retrospectively expressed the fear of [[World War II]] servicemen who had survived the conflict in Europe, of joining the [[Pacific War]].<ref>{{cite book
| first= David 
| last= Evans
| year= 2008
| title= Ramblin' on my Mind: new perspectives on the blues
| edition= 1st
| publisher= University of Illinois Press 
| location= Urbana and Chicago
| isbn=  978-0-252-03203-5
| page= 329}}</ref>

==Biography==
'''William Borum''' was born in [[Shelby County, Tennessee]], [[United States]].<ref name="AMG"/><ref name="Dead"/> He was taught to play the guitar by his father, and [[busking|busked]] with Jack Kelly's Jug Busters in his teenage years.  He quickly moved on to work with the [[Memphis Jug Band]], who played both locally and at the [[Mardi Gras]] in [[New Orleans]]. He extended his repertoire after being taught to play the harmonica by [[Noah Lewis]].<ref name="Blues">{{cite web |url=http://www.thebluestrail.com/artists/mus_mwb.htm |title=William Borum |author= |date= |work= |publisher=Thebluestrail.com |accessdate=October 2011}}</ref>

Willie B. slowly developed away from a disciplined [[jug band]] style, and played at various locations with [[Robert Johnson]], [[Garfield Akers]], [[Sonny Boy Williamson II]] and [[Willie Brown (musician)|Willie Brown]], who periodically travelled up from the [[Mississippi Delta|Delta]] to play.<ref name="AMG"/> Willie B. first recorded at the age of 23, in September 1934 in [[New York City|New York]], for [[Vocalion Records]].<ref name="Wirz">{{cite web |url=http://www.wirz.de/music/memphifrm.htm |title=Memphis Willie B. discography |author= |date= |work= |publisher=Wirz.de |accessdate=October 11, 2011}}</ref>  However, that part of his career was brief as he returned to working locally, in the company of [[Ernest Lawlers|Little Son Joe]], [[Will Shade]] and [[Joe Hill Louis]].<ref name="AMG"/><ref name="Blues"/>  He signed up with the [[United States Army|U.S. Army]] in January 1942, and served in the North African invasion ([[Operation Torch]]) in December 1942, and later in Italy.<ref>{{cite book
| first= Guido
| last= Van Rijn
| year= 2004
| title= The Truman and Eisenhower Blues: African-American Blues and Gospel Songs, 1945-1960
| edition= 1st
| publisher= Continuum 
| location= Athens, Georgia
| isbn= 0-8264-5657-X
| page= 28}}</ref>  

When [[Demobilization|demobilized]] he discovered musician's work hard to find, and eventually took up regular paid employment.  He only returned to the music industry in the early 1960s, and recorded sufficient material for two albums for [[Bluesville Records]] in Memphis in 1961.<ref name="AMG"/><ref name="Wirz"/>  This provided the impetus for a resurgence in his musical career, and Willie B. played at various [[music festival]]s and in [[coffeehouse]]s.  Often he worked alongside [[Gus Cannon]] and [[Furry Lewis]], reliving their mutual early Memphis days.<ref name="AMG"/><ref>{{cite journal |last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date=June 27, 1963 |title= |journal=[[Jet (magazine)|Jet]] |volume= |issue= |page=page 64 |publisher= |doi= |url= |accessdate=October 11, 2011 }}</ref>

Willie B. once stated, "A blues is about something that's real. It's about what a man feels when his wife leaves him, or about some disappointment that happens to him that he can't do anything about. That's why none of these young boys can really sing the blues. They don't know about the things that go into a blues".<ref>{{cite book
| first= Steven Carl 
| last= Tracy
| year= 1999
| title= Write me a few of your lines: a blues reader
| edition= 1st
| publisher= The [[University of Massachusetts Press]] 
| location= Amherst, Massachusetts
| isbn= 1-55849-205-4
| page= 235}}</ref>

However, Willie B. abruptly stopped playing in the late 1960s, and little was heard of him prior to his death in 1993.<ref name="AMG"/><ref name="Dead"/>
